THE MEDICAL REUNION
The first reunion of the graduates
of the Johns Hopkins Medicat School
and Hospital has come and gone. The
occcasion was successsful Leyond all
anticipation. Thirteen classes have
graduated in medicine since the opening of the Medical School in 1893,
and all the classes from 1893 to 1909
were well represented at the reunion.
Nearly two hundred men were present. Not only were many delightful
reminiscences realled, but the occasion proved of much general interest
and seemed to be of such importance
to the University as to warrant a
rather extensive description in the
"News-Letter."
The reunion was planned for Friday and Saturday, May 6th and 7th,
immediately following the meetings
in Washington of the Congress of
Physicians and Surgeons which it
was thought many of the graduates
would attend. Weeks before careful
plans had been made. The medical
members of the Alumni Council appointed temporary secretaries for
each class. In addition to the formal
notices these secretaries wrote per—
sonal letters to the members of their
class urging their attendance at the
reunion. l'erhaps these preliminaries
were not necessary. We found that
the graduates almost unanimously approved holding the reunion, and all
whose work would permit agreed to
.come. As college men they knew
what alumni reunions were and con'eluded at once that this first gathering of the members of the Johns
Hopkins medical clan was to mark
an epoch in the history of the school
and the University.
The festivities began at ten o'clock
on Friday morning with a general
meeting in the Medical amphitheatre.
The room was crowded. Dr. Barker
presided, and in graceful phrases
spoke of the pleasure of the faculty
in welcoming so many of the graduates back and of the pride which the
faculty took in the good work of so
many of the former students. He
then read a letter from President
Remsen, who regretted exceedingly
his inability to respond in person.
The president emphasised the intimate association which had always
existed between the University and
the Medical School and acknowledged
the debt which the University owed
to its Medical Department. He believed that a good medical school
was only possible in connection with
a university, and he hoped that the
medical alumni present here would
realize that much of the spirit and
,T‘nthusiasm which they had displayed

THE MEDICAL REUNION
The first reunion of the graduates
of the Johns Hopkins Medicat School
and Hospital has come and gone. The
occcasion was successsful Leyond all
anticipation. Thirteen classes have
graduated in medicine since the opening of the Medical School in 1893,
and all the classes from 1893 to 1909
were well represented at the reunion.
Nearly two hundred men were present. Not only were many delightful
reminiscences realled, but the occasion proved of much general interest
and seemed to be of such importance
to the University as to warrant a
rather extensive description in the
"News-Letter."
The reunion was planned for Friday and Saturday, May 6th and 7th,
immediately following the meetings
in Washington of the Congress of
Physicians and Surgeons which it
was thought many of the graduates
would attend. Weeks before careful
plans had been made. The medical
members of the Alumni Council appointed temporary secretaries for
each class. In addition to the formal
notices these secretaries wrote per—
sonal letters to the members of their
class urging their attendance at the
reunion. l'erhaps these preliminaries
were not necessary. We found that
the graduates almost unanimously approved holding the reunion, and all
whose work would permit agreed to
.come. As college men they knew
what alumni reunions were and con'eluded at once that this first gathering of the members of the Johns
Hopkins medical clan was to mark
an epoch in the history of the school
and the University.
The festivities began at ten o'clock
on Friday morning with a general
meeting in the Medical amphitheatre.
The room was crowded. Dr. Barker
presided, and in graceful phrases
spoke of the pleasure of the faculty
in welcoming so many of the graduates back and of the pride which the
faculty took in the good work of so
many of the former students. He
then read a letter from President
Remsen, who regretted exceedingly
his inability to respond in person.
The president emphasised the intimate association which had always
existed between the University and
the Medical School and acknowledged
the debt which the University owed
to its Medical Department. He believed that a good medical school
was only possible in connection with
a university, and he hoped that the
medical alumni present here would
realize that much of the spirit and
,T‘nthusiasm which they had displayed
